results.title: The Avengers
results.brief_description: Espionage, fantasy and a healthy dose of unresolved sexual tension abound in this slick series that has proved to be one of the most successful television series of all time. Originally aired in the UK between January 1961 and September 1969 and comprising of 161 episodes, the series went on to screen in a record number of 120 countries. John Steed (Patrick McNee) was always an Avenger, appearing in all episodes - Mrs Peel (Diana Rigg) was his third and most enduring partner. The series was resurrected in the mid 1970s, episodes of which are also available in the collection.

results.title: Death at bargain prices. Castle De'ath. The Master minds
results.creator_credit: Julian Wintle and Associated British Picture Corporation
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “The Avengers”.
Death at bargain prices: When a murdered agent is found carrying a receipt from the children’s section of Pinter’s department store Mrs Peel finds herself working in lingerie. Steed discovers the mysterious disappearance of food from the store as well as regular customer Professor Popple. “Castle De’ath”: Mrs Peel goes undercover as a publicity consultant with ABORCASHAAT (Advisory Bureau on Refurbishing Castles and Stately Homes as a Tourist Attraction) at De’ath Castle; Steed is a kilt wearing historian investigating the 13th Laird of De’ath, Black Jimmy. There’s ghosts of traitors past, mysterious pipers, a dungeon and plenty of tartan from the Avengers. Gordon Jackson stars. “The Master minds”: When Sir Clive Todd is found to be involved with a string of burglaries the government is keen to solve matters quietly and quickly. Mrs Peel plays Florence Nightingale to the amnesiac Sir Clive who was shot in the latest robbery and Steed attempts to find the mastermind behind the successful outfit.

results.title: Die Fledermaus
results.creator_credit: Hugh Davison, Anthony Besch, Brian Adams, ABC and Opera Australia
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “The Australian Opera”.
Recorded live at the Sydney Opera House on July 10th 1982 for television, this famous operetta by Johann Strauss, libretto by Richard Genee and Carl Haffner, has once again proven to be a favourite with the audience. Witty, charming, comical, “Die Fledermaus” is a tale of a philandering husband, a masked ball, a wife disguised in order to trick her philandering husband, of revenge, and of other dubious and mischievous schemes which eventually result in total confusion for one and all - one may ask could it possibly have anything to do with the champagne! The great Joan Sutherland (Rosalinde), along with Robert Gard (Gabriel von Eisenstein) lead a superb cast including Anson Austin (Alfred), Monique Brynnel (Adele), Gordon Wilcock (Blind), Michael Lewis (Dr Falke), Gregory Yurisich (Frank), Graeme Ewer (Frosch), Anne Maree McDonald (Ida), Pieter Van Der Stolk (Ivan) and Heather Begg (Prince Orlofsky). Also features the Australian Opera Chorus with Martin Handley as chorus master, the Elizabethan Sydney Orchestra with Ladislav Jasek as concert master and Richard Bonynge, conductor, and a cameo appearance by Kelvin Coe and Lois Strike from the Sydney Dance Company. The stage-set and design is eloquent in its simplicity, as too the costumes and make-up. An excellent production. Sung and spoken in English.

results.title: Joan Sutherland, Luciano Pavarotti, Richard Bonynge: gala concert
results.creator_credit: Brian Adams, ABC-TV (Australia) and Australian Opera
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “The Australian Opera”.
Recorded live at the Sydney Opera House on January 23, 1983 Joan Sutherland and Luciano Pavarotti perform many favourite arias, together and as soloists. Richard Bonynge conducts the Elizabethan Sydney Orchestra. The operas of Verdi, Puccini, Bellini, Cilea, Massenet, Thomas, Leoncavallo and Donizetti are all represented.

results.title: Lakme
results.creator_credit: John Charles, Cheryl Forrest-Smith and ABC Video Arts
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “The Australian Opera”.
The 1976 performance of Leo Delibes “Lakme” at the Sydney Opera House stars Joan Sutherland, Huguette Tourangeau and Henri Wilden. The story is set in India in the mid 19th Century when the British were imposing a suppressive rule over the many religious sects. Nilakantha, the leader of one of the forbidden sects is secretly raising his daughter Lakme as a priestess to be worshipped as Divine by his followers. He keeps her isolated in a temple which he has surrounded with a bamboo stockade, declaring the temple and garden to be sacred ground. Sung in French. No subtitles. A brief summary of the plot is provided on screen in English at the beginning of each Act. Performers include: Joan Sutherland, Clifford Grant, Huguette Tourangeau, Graeme Ewer, Henri Wilden. The Australian Opera (Sydney) conducted by Richard Bonynge. The Elizabethan Orchestra (Sydney) conducted by Robert Ingram. Geoffrey Arnold (Chorus Master), Australian Opera Chorus. Staged by Michael Kaempff

results.title: You'd have to be mad to like opera
results.creator_credit: Karl McPhee, Gil Brealey and Film Australia
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “The Australian Opera”.
Explores the personality of opera singer Isobel Buchanan, and gives an insight into her life as an opera singer. She is seen in a number of situations which show the wide range of activities and disciplines which go towards the making of an opera. Particular emphasis is placed on rehearsal and actual performance of the opera ‘Don Pasquale’. Production manager, Roy Bissell; director, script, Karl McPhee; editor, Ian Walker; sound, Rodney Simmons; photographer, Andrew Fraser.

results.title: Contemporary Painting (Captioned)
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “The Australian eye V”.
CONTEMPORARY PAINTING (1950)is the seventh part in the renowned Australian Eye Series which traces the history of Australian Painting from colonial to contemporary times. The following artists and their work are examined in detail. Lloyd Rees - The Harbour from McMahon’s Point 1950 Ian Fairweather - Epiphany 1962 Brett Whiteley - Self Portrait in the Studio 1976 Jeffrey Smart - Truck and Trailer Heading into a City 1973 Fred Williams - Waterfall Polyptych 1979 Ten Contemporary Artists - The Creative Eye

results.title: The Creative eye: thoughts on painting by some contemporary artists
results.creator_credit: David Muir, Malcolm Otton and Film Australia
results.brief_description:
Episode number 1 of Series “The Australian eye V”.
The film is intended as a background to the whole “Australian eye” collection. Ten artists, with a variety of styles, are shown working on their paintings and talking about their problems. Students seeing the film should quickly realise that all true artists have to evolve their own methods of realising ideas and that there is no magic formula for achieving good paintings. Artists includes Sally Robinson, Col Jorden, Terrence O’Donnell, Rod Milgate, Suzanne Archer, Peter Powditch, John Firth-Smith, Kevin Conner, Ann Thompson and Alan Oldfield.

results.title: 'Down the hills to Berry's Bay' by Roland Wakelin
results.creator_credit: David Muir, Malcolm Otton and Film Australia
results.brief_description:
Episode number 2 of Series “The Australian eye V”.
Roland Wakelin was a leading figure in the fight to gain recognition in Australia for modernism. “Down the hills” is a powerful composition, introducing a Post-impressionist approach to form and using the Impressionists technique of juxtaposing strokes of pure colour. Wakelin speaks of his ideas in the film.
